Clogged drains, roadside garbage show wa.description: GURUGRAM: State public works department (PWD) minister Rao Narbir Singh on Monday directed the district administration to desilt drains along the Delhi-Jaipur national highway and those on Behrampur road by Thursday. Singh was on an inspection round to take stock of the city’s monsoon preparedness. Earlier this month, deputy commissioner Amit Khatri had directed NHAI and GMDA officials to expedite work on desilting and cleaning drains and roads of garbage, among others, to avoid waterlogging. He directed that special attention be paid to critical points like Signature Towers crossing, Hero Honda Chowk, Subhash Chowk and U-turn near Ambience mall. On the other hand, a visit to several spots aross the city by TOI belied these efforts. Clogged drains, garbage accumulated along the roadside and potholes were visible in many areas. Sectors 34, 37 and 10A, Sheetla Mata Mandir road and areas in and around Hero Honda Chowk are some areas susceptible to flooding even during light showers. Residents of these areas complained of clogged drains, garbage littered everywhere, and construction and demolition waste dumped openly on the roadside. They expressed concerns over the administration’s efforts in ensuring that potholes are repaired, drains are cleaned and garbage is picked up and properly disposed of. “Garbage dumped in the area isn’t managed on time here. Construction waste is dumped along the road and lies unaddressed. Every year, this garbage flows to the drains and chokes them during rains and causes waterlogging. People are forced to travel on roads flooded with sewage,” complained Hariram, a resident of Khandsa village in Sector 37. Residents are also worried that with the expansion of Badshapur drain still incomplete and some drains broken due to construction work on Sohna road, the upcoming monsoon might cause heavy waterlogging.  District administration officials, however, said they have assured the chief minister that the widening of Badshapur drain will be completed by June 30. Speaking on their efforts to contain waterlogging and ensure smooth traffic flow on roads, an NHAI official claimed, “All the departments are coordinating with each other to mitigate this challenge. NHAI has already cleaned several surface drains, and the remaining will be cleaned in the coming days. We’ve also doubled the capacity of the suction pumps installed at Hero Honda Chowk to deal with waterlogging.” The official added that while the department is doing its bit, people too need to be more careful about dumping waste. “Areas falling in wards 24 and 27 are bit of a problem. Haphazard waste dumping is rampant in these areas, which puts pressure on the administration. Area councillors should also rise up to the occasion and counsel people towards better waste disposal practices,” he said. GMDA official too said they are gearing up for the monsoon. “We’ve already cleaned and repaired around 40km of drains in the city to ensure that they don’t clog during rains. Work to cover other drains is underway. We are committed to complete our task before monsoon,” a GMDA official claimed. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AP BJP List 2019.description: NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), on Thursday, announced its first candidate list for the Lok Sabha elections 2019 that includes 184 candidates. The party has named two candidates from Andhra Pradesh in the first list. Kanna Lakshminarayana will contest from Narasaraopet Lok Sabha constituency while D Purandeshwari will contest from the Visakhapatnam seat. Andhra Pradesh will go to polls in a single phase on April 11. BJP's Lok Sabha first full list The Lok Sabha elections will be held in seven phases from April 11 to May 19, 2019. The counting of the votes has been scheduled for May 23. The first phase will be held on April 11, second on April 18, third on April 23 and fourth on April 29, fifth on May 6, sixth on May 12 and seventh phase on May 19. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will contest from Varanasi constituency, while BJP president Amit Shah will fight from Gandhinagar in place of L K Advani. As many as 90 crore electors, including 1.59 crore new voters aged 18-19 years, are registered to vote in the upcoming general election. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Two arrested in Meerut for Gurugram trad.description: GURUGRAM: Two more accused, involved in the murder of the cloth merchant in Sadar Bazar, were arrested from Meerut on Monday night. With this, police claim to have arrested all five accused involved in the case. The accused — Saurabh Kumar (19) and Ajay Kumar (19) told police that they were inspired by the lifestyle most gangsters followed and wanted to be a part of the crime world. They confessed that they were with Suraj Katari —the prime accused in the case — when Sudhir Taneja was shot dead in Sadar Bazar, police said. “Saurabh and Ajay along with Kataria had intercepted Taneja around 9.30pm on May 28, when the trader was returning home after closing his shop. They first tried to snatch the bag containing cash from Taneja at gunpoint, but when he resisted and raised an alarm, they shot him and fled with his scooter,” an officer said. According to the police, Suraj Katari — a history-sheeter against whom more than six cases registered — was arrested from Basai, Manoj, a resident of Kumhar mohalla, was arrested from Mata Mandir while Suraj, a resident of Hathras in UP, was nabbed from Jyoti Park. “The trio’s interrogation gave us vital clues about Saurabh and Ajay. A police team lead by sub-inspector Rajkumar from crime unit of Sector 39 arrested the duo from Meerut on Monday night. Saurabh was so impressed by the crime world that he had also kept a nickname for himself — Mahakal,” an officer said. “The duo have no criminal record and probably this was their first big crime,” said ACP (crime) Shamsher Singh. Lost polls but won hearts: Deepender Sin.description: ROHTAK: Making his first public appearance after being handed defeat in Rohtak Lok Sabha seat by BJP’s Arvind Sharma, former Rohtak MP Deepender Singh Hooda on Sunday said that he may have lost the electoral battle but he won hearts of voters. Addressing a thanksgiving public meeting in Rohtak, Deepender claimed that of the 297 seats in the Hindi heartland, his performance in Rohtak was the best in terms of vote share. Giving credit to party supporters, the former MP said that after Rae Bareli, he got best vote share in Rohtak on account of the hard work of party workers and supporters. Taking on the state’s Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) government led by chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar, he said that days are numbered of those who played the politics of lies and division in the society for their political gains. Talking about his defeat, the three-time MP said that from the top BJP central leadership to the state leadership, all had put their weight in the Rohtak election and the government misused state machinery to defeat him. Responding to BJP minister Manish Grover’s claim that they would defeat former CM Bhupinder Singh Hooda, Deepender said that the minister should refrain from speaking such language, as no force in this world could wipe Hooda father-son from people’s heart. On the victory of newlyelected Rohtak MP Arvind Sharma, the Congress leader Deepender extended his best wishes to the former. On the incumbent BJP government, he said that unemployment in the state had increased at the rate of 8.8% and it was highest in the last 45 years. Mall in trouble as town planner finds vi.description: GURUGRAM: The newly-operational Ardee City Mall and multiplex, spread over 5.1 acres in Sector 52, is under the scanner of the department of town and country planning (DTCP) for violation of its approved building plan and unauthorised construction. The senior town planner (STP) of Gurugram has recommended the cancellation of the occupation certificate (OC) of the mall to the director of DTCP following a complaint filed at the CM’s Window. If this happens, this will be first time the OC of such a big and operational commercial building is cancelled in Gurugram. The developer did not respond to calls and messages from this correspondent. In April 2017, Delhi resident Reena Joon had filed a complaint highlighting illegal construction in the mall. In her complaint, Joon said she had bought a shop on the ground floor of the mall. “My shop was on upper ground floor, but the developer (Ardee) made changes in the building after getting OC and now my shop is on the first floor,” she alleged. Taking cognisance of the complaint, the DTCP director had directed the Gurugram STP to submit a report after investigating the allegations. STP Sudhir Chouhan, DTP (planning) RS Batth and DTP (enforcement) Ved Prakash Shehrawat inspected the mall and submitted their report last week. It highlighted that several violations of building plan were found at the mall and recommended that the OC be cancelled till the developer restores the mall as per the approved building plan. Till the unauthorised construction was removed, the report recommended sealing the mall. “During the inspection, we found several violations. We’ve sent our report to the DTCP director with the recommended for cancellation of OC of the mall and multiplex. The no-objection certificate (NOC) of multiplex has been revoked. The director will take the final call on the issue,” Chouhan said. During the inspection, it was found that no approval had been granted for the construction of a multiplex on the third floor of the mall in the original building plan. According to the report, Ardee has violated the approved building plan and made illegal and unauthorised construction — a store room in the lower basement and a fan room and store room in the upper basement. Moreover, changes had been made in the plan on the lower ground, upper ground, ground, first and second floors. The report further mentioned that the developer is still making additional construction and is a continuous offender by neither abiding by the rules of the department nor maintaining the sanctity of the approved building plan. The mall’s building plan was approved in 2012, and it became functional a few months ago. In Video:Gurugram: Ardee Mall in trouble as town planner finds violationsDownload The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. In Video:Congress refused to forge alliance with AAP for LS polls: KejriwalDownload The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Gurugram: No piped water in IAF buffer a.description: GURUGRAM: Residents of colonies in and around 900m of the Indian Air Force (IAF) ammunition depot in Sector 14 are reeling from acute water shortage. Colonies like Noble Farms, Sadhguru Farms and parts of Ashok Vihar and Dharam colony, which fall within the 300m restricted area, are the worst hit. Though the Punjab and Haryana high court has given its nod for temporary power and water connections to residents of the area until the legality of the colonies is decided, residents here still depend on water tankers and groundwater. While they have demanded that the MCG provide them with water supply, the corporation maintains that connections can't be given as the matter is sub-judice. Residents claimed that in spite of filing petitions in the court to seek temporary services like power and water supply until the final orders on the structures raised in the area are dispensed, their pleas have fell on deaf ears. While their collective efforts did help them avail temporary power connections, water supply remains a distant luxury for many, they said. In the absence of proper supply, residents are either relying on private water tankers or submersible pumps to draw groundwater. The overuse of such pumps has contributed to the deteriorating groundwater situation in the city. According to the Central Ground Water Authority (CGWA), Gurugram is overdrawing its groundwater supply by 300%. As a result, the water table had fallen by 33m in 2014, and the table is receding by 1m every year. Commenting on the existing water supply situation in the area, an MCG official said, “We can’t provide water to households within 300m of the IAF depot as the matter is in court and the structures here have been deemed illegal.” The official further noted that the department has laid down water pipelines in certain pockets that are over and above the 300m range, and the remaining work will completed in coming few months. Removing structures from the area has become one of the biggest infrastructural challenges of the district administration. The legitimacy of the houses and shops within 900m of the depot has been contested in court for years. In 2015, the Centre had told the high court that the restricted zone around the depot had been decreased from 900m to 300m. The court had further asked the district administration to ensure that no new structure is raised in the area. However, residents have claimed that several paying guest accommodations, shops and residential structures have come up in the area even after court orders. Meanwhile, MCG officials have claimed that their demolition drives have faced severe resistance from the inhabitants. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

It\u2019s Now Easier To Talk About Menta.description: At the best of times, mental health is not a topic that lends itself easily to public conversations. The stigma attached to conditions such as depression or anxiety is all too real in India, leaving sufferers despairing of a way out of the darkness. This is where support networks come in, with the offer of a patient and empathetic ear, and (just maybe) the promise of future emotional well-being. Finally, it seems, there’s a window for those who struggle to see the light. Sakshi Virmani reports Hawkers and peddlers swarm the Georgian colonnades of Connaught Place on a busy Sunday evening. Inside Central Park, a group of 15 youngsters huddle together on the dew-drenched grass, unmindful of ardent lovebirds playing peekaboo around them. The session gets underway with an activity in which members are asked to identify a nearby object, something they can relate to. A bespectacled boy picks a bench, someone else chooses a defunct traffic light. At this Offcause meet-up, each of the 15 is being keenly observed by a psychologist, who is helming the hour-long group therapy. Here, you can speak freely about your fears, anxieties and traumas, and, also, share tips on how to get by. The idea is to get everyone talking, to make sure nobody feels left out, by providing a sheltered space and an environment that’s non-judgemental, accommodative and creative. Offcause, for example, lends a hand by encouraging men and women to talk candidly, or to take part in activity-based therapy (painting, dance, improv comedy). More than a few come to listen, some seek succour in the shape of suggestions, yet others draw strength from fellow participants who have emerged from the shadows. “Acknowledging the stigma is the first step, and getting yourself out of the house is another – we self-stigmatise ourselves so much,” claims UK-based Jhilmil Breckenridge, a poet, mental-health activist and founder of Bhor Foundation, an initiative devoted to mental health. Indeed, for the thousands whose days seem perpetually gloomy, an hour or so in the right company might help part the clouds to reveal a ray of sunshine.  LISTENING WITHOUT PREJUDICE Initiatives like Offcause offer a support web for the many overwhelmed by mental health concerns, without the patient having to shell out on a therapist (thus, avoiding the unease of a visit to the psychiatrist). Such collectives comprise individuals whose experiences leave them best suited to help others similarly afflicted. “After I got out of depression, I realised it really helps to talk to somebody who is going through similar issues, as it gives them hope,” admits Mridul Trehan, who credits counseling received by the Delhi Depression Support Group for his recovery. Ujala, a 29-year-old from Jammu, suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and clinical depression. A regular at Offcause meet-ups, Ujala feels that sharing her experiences can be of immense value to fellow sufferers trying to understand the difference between surface and underlying issues. “Personally, I am seeing a psychiatrist and a psychologist for my PTSD and depression, but I love being a part of Offcause — to help others going through various mental disorders,” she says. “You cannot categorise mental illness due to some accident or trigger, it depends on genetics and the way some people’s brains are wired. Some incidents have a ripple effect, they keep playing again and again, which is emotionally consuming,” explains Ujala, who doesn’t just recall incidents, she relives them (like the domestic violence she and her mother have been victims of). For Offcause founder Nikita, it was a causal Instagram update on World Mental Health Day last October that proved the spark. “I asked if people had any stories to share anonymously for the Instagram page I wanted to launch, (and) the response was great – it was surprising to see my closest friends talking about issues they would have never discussed with me on the rare occasions we would meet,” reveals Nikita, who, having left her job just three months earlier, was somewhat at her wit’s end. So, a page was created and the conversations continued. In less than a month, Offcause had its first informal group therapy session. Since then, it has been hosting meet-ups on the third Saturday of every month in Delhi, Gurgaon and Mumbai.  STRIKING THE RIGHT NOTE At an upmarket gastropub in South Delhi, a group of musicians are sharing a laugh over pints of draught beer. They form part of support group Good Vibration, initially launched to discuss problems affecting young musicians, and anybody associated with the industry. Now, anyone can join in, in the monthly meets. Founder Rithika Nayan, a music teacher and certified life coach, commences by talking about anxiety. Soon, the discussion touches on panic attacks, and how best to deal with them. “Scream!” suggests one. “Take a nap!” recommends another, a quick-fix that has everyone nodding in unison. “We millennials are looking for external validation all the time. Blowing things out of proportion in our heads, overthinking and suppressing emotions leads to extreme outbursts. We are never taught how to deal with our emotions intelligently,” explains Rithika to an audience of 12, all absorbed. “Keeping a gratitude journal really helps — counting the small blessings makes a difference,” she offers. According to a 2015-16 survey by Bangalore-based National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences (NIMHANS), 13.7% of India’s general population suffers from a mental ailment. While 150 million Indians are in urgent need of mental health intervention, only 30 million have access to such care. And, according to WHO (World Health Organisation) projections, by 2020 approximately 20% of Indians would be beset by some form of mental illness. Yet, to many in India, mental health still comes with plenty of baggage, and potential loss of face in front of peers. The older generation is reluctant to talk about it and the young think it’s a fad, believes psychologist Dr Ritu Dangwal. She advocates an organised support network. “Support groups are essentially reassurance and reinforcements, more like stopgap arrangements. The groups need to realise that if a person needs extra help, they must guide them to psychiatrists,” she insists. “In India, poor people don’t have the bandwidth to access even basic medical care. But it is heartening to know at least the younger generation is reaching out and saying it’s okay to talk about it.” Dr Dangwal does, however, advise caution. “The tricky part is when everyone starts giving advice. It’s encouraging to have support groups but only to a point — they can address problems at the surface.”  CARE FOR THE CAREGIVERS On a Saturday afternoon last month, a support group of caregivers assembled to discuss family and relationships at Khoj Studios, in the bylanes of Delhi’s Khirki Extension. The Listening Circles provide solace and support not just for those undergoing mental distress, but also for their caregivers, who could be a spouse, parents or children. This support network is moderated by Namarita Kathait, a commissioning editor with a publishing house, and Jhilmil Breckenridge. “We wanted to start a support group that is non-hierarchal, and to get people together in a safe space to have a discourse on mental health,” tells Namarita, 25, who inadvertently became a caregiver for her mother when she was diagnosed with schizophrenia. “I was labelled as the sad girl in school because I did not know how to express what I was going through,” she says, speaking for the many who choose to remain silent. For Jhilmil, it’s important that guidance or advice is not pushed against anyone’s wishes. “People are already vulnerable, we don’t want to force things like meditation and spirituality on them,” she stresses. The next step, says Namarita, is to build ‘listening circles’ with those who have attended the sessions, and to create support groups in their own localities, in colleges and hostels, and among the wider community. “Our ethos is very clear – we are here to listen and we keep it as liberal as possible,” she maintains. “People have the right to speak and not speak, to walk in at any point they want.”  YOU’RE NOT ALONE Then there are youngsters striving to cope with parents who have been diagnosed with a mental illness. It’s this bracket that an upcoming support group network is looking to rally around. Behind the group is Divya Dureja, a counseling psychologist, LGBT activist and TEDx speaker. “If your parent experiences mental illness, it is normal for you to have all kinds of different feelings,” she reasons. “You might not understand why your parents act the way they do. It might be hard to know how to understand your parent, or what to do for them.” Divya believes volunteer caregivers need to be empowered as a first line of defence. “I’ve been building frameworks of mental health support groups that don’t seem to exist in our country,” she explained. “Over the past year, I’ve interacted with over 400 students, primarily studying psychology, at panels, summits and workshops, and (also) those individuals who are looking for resources that are empowering to their mental health.” For, psychological well-being is as critical for the ones who deliver care as for those who receive it. And sanctuary can also be found online. On It’s Ok To Talk, the young can share their innermost thoughts through blogs, poetry, video stories, artwork, even audio recordings. But not only the young. Among the personal accounts on the website is a 58-year-old Gurgaon man’s cry from the heart: ‘Today my heart is brimming painfully with hurt feelings and emotions and there is no one here to share these feelings with or to have a shoulder to cry on little… I have been facing problems linked with depression, schizophrenia and what not since ages now – and with me all my family too…’ Proof that age doesn’t discriminate against the despondent of spirit. It’s Ok To Talk reaches out via digital, social media and on-ground activities, which could include public talks, arts-based events and youth leadership programmes. “Anyone can share stories, of lived experiences of mental health and well-being, and the same will have a tremendous impact on those who may be struggling themselves, and help them realise that they are not alone,” informs Sweta Pal, a member of the Delhi team. “By sharing your own story, you can help inspire other young people that mental health does not need to be shrouded in silence, and it’s ok to talk about it.” Happily, it is becoming easier to talk about mental health, aided by get-togethers that are informal and intimate. And while the fragmented nature of the space means there will always be patients who slip through the cracks, still folks are turning to a growing number of support networks, offering as these do more than a glimmer of hope to the unmoored, the lonely and the vulnerable of India. Spanish intern in Indian IT major raped.description: GURGAON: A 23-year-old Spanish woman filed a police complaint on Saturday, accusing a Delhi-based filmmaker who she recently befriended of raping her after inviting her to a party at his bungalow in DLF-1. Police said the woman is a student of software engineering and had come to India for a year-long internship with an Indian IT major. She had taken up accommodation in Gurgaon and was looking to shift homes when, on a Facebook group, she came across the suspect, a man police identified as Aanjaney. Investigators said he was 36 years old, worked in a production house making animation films, and is an original resident of Anand Vihar in Delhi but was currently living in Gurgaon. Police arrested Aanjaney on Saturday. He was charged him under sections 376 (rape) and 342 (wrongful confinement) of the IPC at DLF-1 police station. She said no to sex, he forced himself on herIn her complaint, filed with the help of a friend who acted as a translator, the Spanish woman said Aanjaney had invited her to his house in DLF-1for a party on June 14 and she had reached around 10.30pm. She told cops she trusted him enough to go to his place. “After a few hours we started kissing, and we went upstairs to his room. But I did not feel comfortable with the idea of having sex, so I asked him to stop. He then asked me to spend at least the night there, and I agreed,” she said in her complaint. She claimed she had fallen asleep but woken up a while later and found Aanjaney was still in the room and was masturbating looking at her. “I felt very uncomfortable so I decided to return my house but he didn’t let me. I clearly said I was uncomfortable, I didn’t want to have sex but he forced me to stay and raped me. I had to go through the humiliation because I was afraid if I did not do what he asked, it would get worse. He closed the main door, threw my phone away, and forced himself on me,” she alleged. Police said they were first informed about the alleged sexual assault through a phone call to the control room around 9am on Saturday. The Spanish woman came across Aanjaney only on June 12 during her house hunt, investigators said. They hit it off well, so when he called her to the party, she agreed. “I saw a post from Aanjaney offering a room and we got in touch for that,” she said in her complaint. Police said the she was taken for a medical test and her statement was subsequently recorded at a city court. Police said Aanjaney works in an Udyog Viharbased company. He was single and has been living in the DLF-1 bungalow, which they had rented, since January this year with three friends. Ved Prakash, SHO of DLF-1 police station, said, “Altogether, five persons, including the accused and the Spanish woman, were present at the party. The accused invited two friends and one of his housemates. The housemate went to sleep some time later and the two friends went home. When everybody left, he took her to his room and raped her. On Saturday morning, the Spanish woman called a friend who stays in Sector 10, booked a cab and went to her place. They came back together to file the complaint.” Karan Goyal, ACP (DLF), said the accused had admitted to his crime during questioning and would be taken to court for a decision on his custody. DTCP to challenge district court\u2019s.description: GURUGRAM: The department of town and country planning (DTCP) has decided to approach the Punjab and Haryana high court against the decision of the district court to de-seal the residential properties, which were sealed by the department for illegally running commercial activities. The district court on June 6 ordered the department to de-seal four out of 13 residential properties in DLF 1 and Golf Course Road which were sealed by the department last month for running illegal commercial activities from residential establishments. After the action, the property owners had approached the district court. Around 30 commercial establishments, being run from five residential buildings on Golf Course Road were sealed last month. The enforcement wing of department of town and country planning (DTCP) swung into action after its director KM Pandurang ordered officials to seal the illegal establishments. Earlier, the planning wing of the department had cancelled occupation certificates of 38 residential buildings situated on Golf Course Road and Sushant Lok 1 after a team of officials found that illegal commercial activities were going on in these buildings. District town planner (enforcement) Ved Prakash Sehrawat said, “The department will file a petition against the district court and ensure that the property owners, who were illegally running commercial activities from residential properties, do not go scot free.” As per rules, commercial activities are not allowed in residential areas, be it licensed colonies that come under DTCP or plots in sectors falling under Haryana Shahari Vikas Pradhikaran (HSVP). Medicos take to streets in Ambala.description: AMBALA: The doctors associated with the Indian Medical Association (IMA) in Ambala on Monday held a protest march in the city after withdrawing all non-essential services. They also submitted a memorandum to the chief minister and state health minister demanding a law against hospital violence. Around 9am, several medical practitioners gathered in front of Loomba Hospital from where they started the protest march carrying banners and shouting slogans under the leadership of IMA Ambala Cantonment president Dr Parbhakar Sharma. They marched through Nicholson Road, Sadar Bazaar Chowk, Gurh Mandi, Vegetable Market and other areas. The protesting doctors said, “We should be given proper security. In West Bengal, doctors are forced to work under constant fear. We have suspended all OPD services while the emergency wings will continue to function. We demand a national law against hospital violence and it should be dealt with seriously.” On the other hand, government hospital OPDs were closed due to the gazetted holiday of Saint Kabir Jayanti and several government doctors also joined the IMA march. CMO Ambala Dr SL Verma said, “The emergency services in government hospitals are running normally but the OPD was shut due to holiday. We have deployed additional doctors for emergency services to avoid rush at the hospitals. Some IMA members also visited my office to hand over the memorandum of demands.” State health minister Anil Vij said, “Giving protection to doctors is the responsibility of the state government.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Ambala youths allege unabated drug trade.description: AMBALA: Around 15 youths of Shahpur village in Ambala district on Monday held a press conference at public welfare department rest house in Ambala Cantonment regarding prevalent drug abuse in the district. Addressing the press conference one of the youths, Gursewak Singh, 26, claimed that he started consuming heroin in 2018, but has now completely given up on his addiction. Gursewak claimed, “There is no stringent check on heroin smuggling in Ambala Cantonment area and it is being sold at the price of Rs 2,000-2,500 per gram. The government must keep a check on this menace and on the lines of Punjab government they should provide free medicines to the drug-addicts at de-addiction centers.” The youths who left the drugs initiated a campaign ‘Udta Ambala Ujadta Ambala, Maine Chhorha Tum Bhi Chhorho’ to motivate those who are willing to get away from the drug abuse. The youths were supported by the Indian National Lok Dal local leader Onkar Singh who said, “These youths are special that they have spoken out about their struggle of drug abuse. Most of the drug abusers do not come forward in society and with time they become criminals. We will support their initiative and work to bring forward more youths from other villages of Ambala district to fight with the drug menace.” When questioned about claims by youths, Ambala Cantonment DSP Ram Kumar said, "The police is already taking strict action against the drug smugglers and whenever we receive any inputs our teams work immediately. Even on Monday, our CIA teams have recovered 20-gram heroin under limits of Ambala Cantonment police station and a case under relevant Sections of the NDPS Act has been registered." 575 doctors in Gurugram join strike, mos.description: GURUGRAM: Around 250 elective procedures were put on hold across Gurugram’s many healthcare facilities — both in private hospitals, clinics and the state-run Civil Hospital — after 575 doctors in the city (data shared by IMA-Gurugram) joined the Indian Medical Association (IMA) -organised protest on Monday. OPDs in private and state hospitals also remained shut. Curie Rani, whose elderly father was operated upon last week for hernia at Medanta, and had come from Greater Noida for a follow-up consultation, was stopped from going to the OPD, as it was shut. “I’ve been asked to contact the hospital’s helpline number. My father can hardly walk and I can’t make him travel repeatedly after a surgery. I just hope the hospital staff helps me out,” she said. Sources said Medanta had informed all patients whose appointments were scheduled for Monday that OPDs will remain shut as the doctors would join the IMA protest. Sources said while IMA members did not attend OPDs in Medanta, they provided all other essential services, including surgeries, procedures and investigations. The hospital had advised patients to attend OPDs on Tuesday or Wednesday. The OPD at Civil Hospital was also shut as the doctors joined the protest. “We were informed that Civil Hospital doctors had suspended their OPDs, which usually does not happen, since being a government set-up. But we were overwhelmed by the response. Around 575 doctors in Gurugram suspended non-essential services as well as around 250 elective procedures in hospitals and clinics across Gurugram,” said Dr Ajay Gupta, secretary, IMA-Gurugram. “I cancelled my professional commitments as I had to see a doctor. But when I arrived, I got to know the OPD is closed. Now I’ll have to plan another visit again,” said a disappointed Kapil Gugnani. A majority of doctors at private hospitals, including Fortis, Artemis and Medanata, had joined the IMA protest. At some hospitals, OPDs were completely shut, but some patients were allowed to consult doctors. “Sometimes, results don’t go as expected. Violence is not the way to sort out things. Sometimes it becomes difficult to handle patients and their relatives at the same time. Doctors should have adequate protection, and patients should behave in a civilised manner to understand what the condition of the patient actually was when he/she was brought to the hospital,” said Dr Himanshu Tyagi of Artemis. The protest will conclude at 6am on Tuesday. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Chronic congestion: Gurugram has 22 pain.description: GURUGRAM: Traffic police have identified 22 spots in the city as chronic congestion-prone areas, based on traffic records for the months of April and May. In the past two months, 381 instances of traffic congestion have been reported from these areas, revealed the cumulative data compiled by the department. That includes 197 instances of traffic jams from the 22 spots in April, and 184 instances from 15 areas in May. Closer analysis of the data reveals most instances of traffic congestion have been reported from seven spots, namely, Sirhaul toll plaza, Signature Towers, Sheetla Mata mandir road, Ghata mod, Atlas FoB, Daultabad flyover and Tikri cut, which accounted for about 60% of the total number of jams. Of these, Sirhual toll recorded the maximum number of congestions, 47, followed closely by Signature Towers with 43 and 33 at Ghata mod. The data also reveals that duration of these jams range from 1.5 minutes to 5 hours. The longest congestion for the two months was in Sirhaul toll. The spot witnessed a 5-hour-long jam in April, as well as a two-hour-long jam in May. Following Sirhaul in the list, Atlas FoB and Ghata mod recorded long jams of about 50 minutes to an hour each. Commenting on Sirhaul, DCP (traffic) Himanshu Garg told TOI, “Sirhaul is the most challenging area due to a huge bottleneck. About 21 lanes on the Gurugram side converge into 4 lanes on the Delhi side, leading to heavy congestion.” He added that the data reports and subsequent inspections of the area by senior officials, including himself, has helped address a lot of challenges, like fixing of a sharp turn at Dwarka link road. Gurugram’s vulnerability to perennial traffic snarls is one thing that unites all denizens of Millennium City, which is otherwise is a city of contradictions. Be it commuters from neighbouring cities or residents, the congestion affects all. As a result, traffic cops and their efforts are always under scanner. To find a lasting solution, traffic police resorted to gathering and analysing data earlier this year. The department claimed not only does the exercise help them keep a track on major congestion spots, so that they can deploy force to ease traffic flow, but also help them devise policy and carry out enforcement drives. The department records data daily, which is complied as monthly reports that act as a good reference point for the department. “Through these reports, we identify priority areas and devise strategy to manage traffic flow, from spots that need deployment of additional forces or barricades, to cuts in the media that need to be opened or closed, etc. Based on these reports, our officials visit key areas to figure root causes of problems. If it’s a structural issue like faulty roads, we speak to the concerned department to resolve the issue,” said Garg. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\nJim Sarbh's fashionable outing in Gurg.description: 'Padmaavat' actor Jim Sarbh was in town recently, attending a fashion event. Clad in a sleeveless hand-embroidered high-quality multi-functional jacket, the actor was seen sharing nitty-gritties of acting and his idea about fashion and style. The musical afternoon was organised at a pub in Gurgaon. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

10 junctions in New Gurugram to get 100.description: GURUGRAM: To monitor the traffic movement and carry out surveillance at major junctions in the city, the Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA) is all set to start work on its much talked about project — Public Safety and Adaptive Traffic Management System — in a few weeks. Divided in three phases, GMDA plans to install 220 CCTV cameras in the first phase. Around 100 cameras will be installed at 10 junctions in New Gurugram and will be connected to the integrated control and command centre (ICCC). According to the officials , the survey of these 10 junctions has been completed and the installation work will be completed by July second week. There will be nine monitoring stations — the ICCC and eight police stations. “The feed from the cameras will be displayed at the ICCC and will be monitored by an internal team. Once we finish installing these 100 cameras, we will start work on the installation of the other 120 cameras,” a GMDA official said. He added that the feed from these cameras will be put into various analytics software such as facial recognition, speed violation detection system, e-challans, automatic number plate recognition system and signal violation detection system and the output will be used by GMDA, Gurugram police and other government agencies. “We will be using different types of camera, including general surveillance, PTZ (pan–tilt–zoom), automatic number plate recognition and traffic signal violation detection cameras. This system will help us identify repeat offenders too,” an official said. In all, 360 CCTV cameras will be installed across the city, in phases, under the smart city project. Meanwhile, the work at the ICCC is almost complete and the command and control centre will be functional by mid-July. TOI had earlier reported that the Gurugram police and the administration will have advanced technology to aid their public safety and traffic management system as the GMDA’s CCTV camera project kicks in. The project will start with the cameras being installed at 220 intersections in its first leg. Another 140 intersections will be covered subsequently. In the pre-implementation phase, GMDA had surveyed the junctions, set the layout and the monitoring facility at the intersections and police stations. A preliminary survey had already been done by the authority where they have made detailed drawings of all the junctions and identified the number and category of cameras required at those junctions. “We have already decided the placement, number and type of cameras with the help of the survey,” an official said. Times Impact: Brisk Lumbini to get power.description: GURUGRAM: In a major relief to over 100 families living in Brisk Lumbini Terrace Homes, Sector 109, the department of town and country planning (DTCP) has cleared the way for the set-up of a sub-station for power supply to the society. For three years, residents have been living without official power connections from the state government and are dependent on diesel gensets, which cause noise and air pollution. On June 5, TOI had reported that after over three years of getting the possession of their flats, Brisk Lumbini were living without electricity. Following the publication of the TOI report, the district town planner held several meetings with residents, and the developer was directed to provide land for a sub-station. The developer offered a plot of 500 sq yards to the department. After inspection, DTCP gave its approval on June 12. “DHBVN will start the construction of sub-station once the developer fulfils the conditions of external development charges and other norms,” district town planner (planning) RS Batth said. Gurugram: MG Road stays bumpy, littered.description: GURUGRAM: Damaged dividers, footpaths either broken or encroached upon, carriageways riddled with patchwork and potholes and illegal parking on the roadside. This sums up a visitor’s experience of the city’s arterial link — MG Road. With numerous malls, residential apartments, public and private offices along it, the road is forever jam-packed with commuters, especially during peak hours. The volume of traffic can be gauged from the presence of two of the city’s main metro stations here — MG Road and Sikanderpur — used daily by lakhs of officegoers from the city and its NCR neighbours. The administration has made many commitments in the past towards maintaining and beautifying the stretch. Last year, many master roads in the city, including MG Road, were transferred to GMDA. In December 2018, the department had announced that it would conduct repair and maintenance work on 12 stretches by March. However, TOI’s visit revealed that six months later, MG Road is still in a bad shape. Apart from the poor condition of the surface, chronic traffic jams during peak office hours, often due to wrong-side driving that broken dividers and illegal parking seem to encourage, make commute a harrowing experience on this road. Commenting on the GMDA’s efforts to address the challenges posed by this stretch, an official revealed the department is rolling out a Rs 11-crore project to upgrade it. “The tender has been allotted to a private firm that will repair this stretch — from Mehrauli-Gurugram Road to IFFCO Chowk, via Sikanderpur road — by layering bitumen all over. The contractor will also be liable for its maintenance for three years from the time work is completed,” the official said. He further pointed out that while earlier repair work on this stretch came under the department’s annual maintenance, the current project is listed as a special repair work. The 15m-green belt on either side is also in a deplorable state, with garbage, including C&D waste, littered on it and spilling over on the road. Commuters fear if the administration doesn’t take prompt action, this could spell doom in the monsoons. “I don’t know why we even call this a green belt. Fences lie broken, garbage is littered on it with no one to clean that. It’s as if the administration will wake up only during monsoon when garbage floods the road and chokes the drains,” said Nirmit, a commuter from Delhi. Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil.
